The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
[Reference CalARP Regulation CCR 2745.3(a)]

The Districts goal is to prevent accidental releases of chlorine gas. The Districts accidental
release prevention strategy incorporates operator training, periodic audits, standard operating
procedures, regularly scheduled maintenance, management practices, continuous system
monitoring, and current technology to achieve its goals. Additionally, applicable provisions of
Federal, State, and Local regulations are followed to ensure compliance and prevention of
accidental releases.
In the unlikely event of a release, this plan addresses the response to emergencies by the District and coordination with response agencies that may be involved. In addition, the District has prepared an Emergency Response Plan to address an alarm scenario. Training includes
instruction on using emergency response equipment and following proper procedures in the
event of a chlorine release. A copy of the Emergency Response Plan is included as Appendix A.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
[Reference CalARP Regulation 19 CCR 2745.3(b)]

The District operates a Drinking Water Chlorination Facility that adds chlorine gas to groundwater that is pumped from the Coyote Valley Basin. Chlorine gas is injected at the wellhead before the groundwater enters the distribution system.
The Drinking Water Chlorination Facility is a small structure that stores chlorine cylinders and
houses equipment that controls and supplies the chlorine gas to the wellhead. The maximum of
three 150-pound chlorine gas cylinders on site at any one time is permissible. These cylinders can be full or empty. Two cylinders are connected to the chlorination system and one is in reserve. When the pressure in the active cylinder falls below 20 pounds per square inch (psi), an automatic switchover system places the reserve cylinder online while allowing the first cylinder to depressurize to ambient pre

ssure. The first cylinder is replaced with the reserve cylinder and the cycle continues. Pressurized chlorine gas flows through the cylinder valve directly into the
chlorinator.

Note: There is no pressurized piping between the cylinder valve and the chlorinator.

The chlorinator reduces the chlorine gas pressure to less than atmospheric and regulates the
chlorine gas flow rate. Chlorine gas under a negative air pressure flows through piping passing
through the automatic switchover system, a gas flow measuring device, and to the ejector where it is mixed with the groundwater.
Note: A more detailed description of the process with diagrams is provided in the Chlorine System Operating Procedures included in Appendix B.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps
[Reference CalARP Regulation 19 CCR 2745.3(c)]

The District has in place the following general strategies to help prevent the release of chlorine
gas:
 Regularly scheduled maintenance of the chlorine system
 A defined management system that defines roles and responsibilities
 Written operating and emergency procedures
 Readily available information to plant operators
 Training for gas handling and use of emergency repair kits
 Continuous system monitoring
 A proactive incident investigation process

The Five-Year Accident History
[Reference CalARP Regulation 19 CCR 2745.3(d)]

No accidental chlorine releases have occurred at the Drinking Water Chlorination Facility in the
past five-years that have resulted in any of the following:
 Onsite/Offsite Deaths
 Onsite/Offsite Injuries
 Significant Onsite and/or Offsite Property Damage
 Offsite Evacuations
 Offsite Sheltering in Place
 Offsite Environmental Damage

The Emergency Response Program
[Reference CalARP Regulation 19 CCR 2745.3(e),19 CCR 2765.1(b)(1)]

The Districts Emergency Response Plan defines who the first responders are and designates the
roles played in an event of a chlorine gas leak as outlined in t

he Districts Emergency Response
Plan in Appendix A.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
[Reference CalARP Regulation 19 CCR 2745.3(f)]

After completing the Process Hazard Analysis the following safety improvements were
recommended, and changes were made to the chlorination system:
1. A facility study of possibly using hypochlorite to replace chlorine gas was recommended
and made; it was found that the change would not be feasible.
2. The prevention of chlorine gas releases from the chlorination system is dependent of the proper operation of the chlorinator valve that is attached to the 150-pound cylinders. Because of this the chlorinator valve receives regularly scheduled maintenance according to the manufacturers recommendations by a factory trained and authorized repair person using factory authorized replacement parts.
3. There are other components of the chlorination system that also need to be maintained
on a regular basis according to the manufacturers recommendations and procedures.
Maintenance is documented through routine maintenance checklists (see Appendix C).
4. Maintenance of the chlorinator valve and other system components is tracked using a
system that continues to provide reminders until the maintenance is completed.
5. There is a battery backup for the chlorine detector.
6. Maintenance of the detector is performed according to manufacturers recommendations.
7. The location of the emergency respirators, personal protective equipment, and chlorine
repair kit is in an easy access location safely away from the chlorine storage area at the
Wastewater Treatment Plant.
8. External detectors installed around the facility provide valuable data if chlorine gas were to escape from the chlorine storage area.
9. On-call operators are equipped with handheld portable chlorine monitors if they are called to respond to a chlorine gas alarm. Operators are trained on the proper operation and calibration of the units.
10. Employees are trained in using the Emergen

cy Response Plan; training is documented.
11. For contractors that will be working on or near the chlorine system or for vendors providing chlorine gas, their contracts are required to take the necessary precautions to prevent the accidents that could result in a chlorine release and require training of their employees on appropriate actions to take in the event of a chlorine alarm or release. This training may need to be provided by the District.
12. Periodic inspections of chlorine storage and use areas for leaks, system damage or corrosion, stored items that could fall and damage chlorine system components, proper storage for chlorine gas cylinders, proper maintenance and storage use to prevents fires, etc. are completed and documented.
13. Inspections are conducted before loading and unloading chlorine cylinders.
14. Written procedures for handling chlorine cylinders are available.
15. A Lockout/Tagout program is used.
